The current x (the replacement for this zero) can be chosen between -k and k, but also such that the remaining (br-1) zeros can sum to (R -x). So the constraints are:

=> 

R - (br-1)*k ≤ x ≤ R + (br-1)*k 

Also, x must be between -k and k. 

So combining all constraints:

x must be in the intersection of [ -k, k ] and [ R - (br-1)*k, R + (br-1)*k ]

children.text: The current contribution from the zeros processed so far (including this one) is (current_sum_after_this_step - s1). So the remaining zeros must contribute (S_needed - (current_sum_after_this_step - s1)). The remaining zeros are (br-1). The remaining required sum is R = (S_needed - (current_sum_after_this_step - s1)).
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
The remaining zeros must sum to R. 

The maximum possible contribution from the remaining zeros is (br-1)*k, the minimum is -(br-1)*k. So R must be between - (br-1)*k and (br-1)*k. Thus, for this x to be valid, R must be within that range. The current x can be chosen between -k and k, but also such that R is within the allowed range. The maximum possible x is the minimum between k and (R_max + ...).
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Alternatively, the code's x is computed as the maximum possible value (k) that allows the remaining zeros to reach the required sum. The maximum possible x is the minimum between k and (S_needed - (current_sum - s1) + (br-1)*k).
children.label: code_analysis
